description.p: Leveraging the full power of XSLT, Symphony gives you what few other templating systems can: the ability to publish in nearly any format, to control every single character you output, and to maintain a complete separation between content and presentation.

From the inside out, Symphony is rooted in the very same principles that you adhere to in your own work. Openness. Standards compliance. Flexibility. Symphony doesn’t just help you get the job done, it helps you get the job done right.

Symphony doesn’t tell you what kind of content to manage, or how. It doesn’t lock you into a rigid structure or dictate some silly URL schema. It just gives you the tools and stays out of your way. Trust us, you’ll like it.

Leveraging the full power of XSLT, Symphony gives you what few other templating systems can: the ability to publish in nearly any format, to control every single character you output, and to maintain a complete separation between content and presentation.
The best interfaces are the ones you barely notice. Symphony’s back end is all about workflow, dispensing with the proverbial bells and whistles and focusing on helping you complete the task at hand.

We love Symphony. And when you love something, you take care of it. Whether it’s the core team improving the system or writing documentation, or community members building extensions and helping newbies on the forum, the people here are generous, industrious, and quite often brilliant. You’ll be glad you joined us.

Inclusion. Conditionals. Parameters. Functions. Recursion. XSLT is a remarkably robust templating language that allows you to keep all your presentational logic right where it belongs. And it’s a widely-used open standard, meaning resources are plentiful and knowledge is not tied to any platform.

XSLT makes it possible to output much more than just web pages. Generate dynamic CSS and JavaScript. Offer RSS and Atom feeds. Whip up PDFs, SVGs, or spreadsheets. Set up an entire XML/JSON API. Virtually any data format is just a template away.

XSLT is rule-based, like CSS. The beauty of rules is that you can write modular, reusable code, which makes maintenance a breeze and allows for rapid prototyping. Reusable bits of XSLT, called Utilities, can be shared throughout a project, and our website has a growing library of XSLT Utilities that you can use right now.

headline.p: Keep your code lean and DRY

description.p: Dynamically generate resized or cropped versions of your images simply by using a specially-formed src URL. Need a 100x100 thumbnail? . Need to bump it to 150 a few weeks later? Just change the URL and Symphony does the rest, including caching. Oh, and it works on external images too.

caption.p: Page templates harness the power of XSLT and can include reusable snippets called utilities.
Utilities are reusable XSLT stylesheets that can be shared throughout your project.
